In a world without the rigid concepts of good and bad, "evil" can be understood not as an absolute force, but as a relative experience. Spiritual teachings suggest that dualities like good and evil exist because of our limited perception‚Äîour attachment to duality is a reflection of the mind‚Äôs inability to grasp the wholeness of existence. From a higher perspective, everything is a manifestation of the divine, a part of the unfolding cosmic dance.

Evil, in this context, becomes a construct of the ego‚Äîa reflection of ignorance and separation. It is not the opposite of good, but rather a distortion of the self‚Äôs alignment with the divine truth. The soul, in its purity, transcends such labels. The real ‚Äúevil‚Äù lies in the disconnect from one‚Äôs true nature, which leads to suffering and ignorance.

In spiritual terms, "evil" is merely a misalignment, a temporary state of imbalance in the flow of divine consciousness. The path of awakening, then, is about transcending dualities and realizing the unity in all things. Thus, in the absence of good and bad, ‚Äúevil‚Äù simply dissolves into the oneness of existence.

postsData.content:
There's something really strange about trust. 


Mikael Gorbachev famously said "–î–æ–≤–µ—Ä—è–π –Ω–æ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä—è–π" which means trust but verify.

But how often do we verify, then trust?

Every time I get on a plane, my life is in the hands of complete strangers and my thoughts are usually

- is it properly maintained?
- is the pilot good, rested, sane?
- did security do its job?
- will they have those cookies I like?

Do we require any evidence of any of those things prior to boarding?

Never!

We blindly trust that the system is going to work as it should.

Why do we trust so much more when the stakes are higher than anything we can imagine?

Why when it's something like a restaurant, a coach, a car, a Linkedin service, anything that's trivial by comparison

we do hours of research before we can commit to it?

I dont want to answer this question, instead, tell me what you all think?

Happy Friday, let's start a discussion

Yours truthfully,

comments.commentText: When we fly, we choose a company with a brand name. Our expectations can change - is there an incident on the plane, are the bathrooms smelly, did they lose my luggage.... There are barriers to entry, so the concentration of players and regulation, so that in and of itself contributes to trust. But some of the small things don't. This is where IRL and WOM are so important, Michael Kainatsky. Just my 2 cents.
you're not wrong there, I agree.

It's faith walk .. every thing we do we belief and trust it will work. Why write a post if you don't have faith and trust that your IHP will read it. That is my two sense.. Happy Friday captain Michael, fasten your seat belts , get ready for push back I am your copilot .. where we flying to today captain Michael Kainatsky ?
elaborate on that? BBB?

postsData.content:
You will never feel 100% ready.

That's the hard truth you need to accept.

Your mind will always find a reason to wait:

 "I need more experience."
 "Maybe I should wait for the right time."
 "What if I fail?"

The perfect moment will never come. Stop waiting and do this instead:

1. Shift your mindset.
 Pay attention to your self-talk and replace doubt with encouragement.
 Speak to yourself the way you would support a friend.

2. Take imperfect action.
 Small, consistent steps lead to big results.
 Clarity comes from doing, not overthinking.

3. Use what you already know.
 Write down 3 wins that prove you're capable.
 Build on your existing skills.

4. Set clear deadlines.
 Replace "later" with a specific date and time.
 Hold yourself accountable with reminders and check-ins.

5. Protect your focus.
 Identify what's stealing your time and energy.
 Set boundaries to keep distractions away.

The most successful people don't have all the answers.

They take action before they feel ready.

You can, too. Start today.

What's one thing you'll take action on right now?

Repost to help someone get started.
Followfor more.

comments.commentText: This is a powerful reminder! Waiting for the 'perfect moment' is the biggest trap. As an SEO expert and digital marketing consultant, I‚Äôve seen so many businesses delay action because they feel unprepared. The truth? Progress comes from starting, learning, and improving along the way. Taking imperfect action is the real game-changer!

postsData.commentAdded: Love this! Taking that first step is often the hardest, but it leads to growth. Lets embrace imperfection and start today! üí™‚ú® #ActionMatters

Jordan Murphy üß†ü¶ç
postsData.content:
Marvel went bankrupt in 1996.

Today, they‚Äôre a $200B empire.

‚Üì

In '96, Marvel was drowning in debt, facing extinction:

1. Comic sales collapsed
2. Their stock‚Äîfreefalling
3. Bankruptcy loomed

Then they made ONE desperate move that transformed them into a $200B entertainment empire...

Here's the incredible story:

‚Üì

The mid-90s were brutal for Marvel:

Comic book sales were plummeting. Their expansion into trading cards and stickers backfired.

With mounting losses + crushing debt, they faced two choices...

‚Üí Sell their heroes for quick cash
‚Üí Find a new way to survive

‚Üì

December 27, 1996: Marvel files for bankruptcy.

But in this crisis, they discovered something crucial:

‚Üí They weren't just a comic book company

They owned 7,000+ characters‚Äîone of the most valuable IP libraries in entertainment history.

‚Üì

It clicked for Marvel's leadership:

Movies could reach millions‚Äîcomics couldn't.

Rather than sell their characters outright, they developed a brilliant strategy:

‚Ä¢ License some characters to studios
‚Ä¢ Keep key heroes for future projects
‚Ä¢ Learn the movie business

‚Üì

They started by licensing Spider-Man to Sony and X-Men to Fox.

This was genius:

They could generate rev + learn from established studios‚Äîwithout risking their capital.

But they held onto lesser-known characters like Iron Man and Thor.

Everyone thought they were crazy.

‚Üì

The licensing deals gave Marvel something precious:

‚Ä¢ Steady revenue
‚Ä¢ Movie-making experience
‚Ä¢ Proof their characters could succeed on screen

When Spider-Man (2002) became a massive hit, it validated their entire strategy.

‚Üì

With growing confidence, Marvel made their boldest move:

Creating Marvel Studios to produce their own films.

The goal?
Build an interconnected universe of stories.

Studios called it impossible.
Investors were skeptical.

Then came 2008...

‚Üì

Iron Man releases in theaters.

A "B-list" hero most people didn't know becomes a global phenom.

Marvel proved something powerful:
Great storytelling could turn ANY character into a star.

Disney was watching.

‚Üì

2009: Disney acquires Marvel for $4.3 billion.

Critics called it overpriced.
They were wrong...

The Marvel Cinematic Universe has since:

‚Üí Broken box office records
‚Üí Revolutionized storytelling
‚Üí Created a new movie model
‚Üí Transformed entertainment

‚Üì

The irony?

Marvel built their empire largely without their most famous characters‚ÄîSpider-Man and X-Men.

They turned "2nd-tier" heroes into global icons.

This reveals something crucial about business:

‚Üì

Your greatest asset isn't always obvious.
Marvel thought they were in comics.

Truth?
They were master storytellers.

The medium wasn't their strength.
Their ability to create compelling narratives was.

‚Üì

Key Lessons:

1. Crisis forces innovation
2. Build systems, not just products
3. Think beyond your current market
4. Your "weakness" might be your edge
5. Sometimes the best assets aren't the obvious ones

‚Üì

Which (1-5) hits for you? 
Hit the Repost Ô∏è

comments.commentText: Marvel didn‚Äôt just survive‚Äîthey reinvented themselves. Adaptation is everything.

postsData.commentAdded: Incredible transformation! üåü Your point on crisis driving innovation really resonates‚Äîsuch a powerful reminder to leverage our hidden strengths! üí™‚ú®

postsData.content:
Burnout is stealing your success.
6 warning signs you can‚Äôt ignore.

Exhausted, productivity slipping, motivation fading.

Burnout isn‚Äôt just exhaustion.
It‚Äôs draining your energy and limiting your potential.

6 signs to break the cycle and take back control.

1. Success hides exhaustion until burnout hits.
‚Üí High achievers often miss their own warning signs
‚Üí Begin tracking energy levels, not just results

2. Toughness turns into denial of limits.
‚Üí Being "tough" masks early warning signs
‚Üí Create weekly check-ins with yourself

3. Excellence locks you in unsustainable cycles.
‚Üí High output becomes your new normal
‚Üí Measure recovery time, not just performance

4. Work achievements consume your identity.
‚Üí Your work becomes your whole identity
‚Üí List three non-work wins every day

5. Competence disguises exhaustion.
‚Üí Everyone thinks you're fine because you deliver
‚Üí Share struggles with trusted allies

6. High standards become energy-draining handcuffs.
‚Üí Your reputation for quality becomes a prison
‚Üí Define "good enough" criteria before starting


Burnout isn't a badge of honour.

It's a signal your success is costing too much.

What exactly can 1st ballad hall of famer Derek Jeter, (Jeets for short.) Possibly teach you and I about how to look at major long term success!)


For the the record. The image with this particular post. (Is not of Derek Jeter. )

It's just a photo of someone playing baseball, okay?

But for those of you who may or may not already be familiar. With former New York Yankee, all time great Derek Jeter.

He played Short Stop his entire career. And played only for the Yankees his entire major league baseball career as well!

He has since retired. And been inducted into the American Baseball Hall of Fame! On the very 1st ballot.

-However, please be mindful of of some of his career stats.

-First, Jeets had 260 total career homeruns. He's not even in the top ten all time. For the Yankees. For that particular stat!

-And he's not even close! With regards to all of major league baseball!

-He also had an impressive 3,465 total career hits.

-Which to date. Makes him the Yankees all time player. With the most combined hits! In the history of the entire storied franchise! (You go cat!)

-Think about that for just a moment. (More total hits than former Yankee legends.

-Like Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle, Don Mattingly or slugger Reggie Jackson etc!

-Next please take notice of his career hitting average .310. (For his entire 20 year big league career!

-But let's interpret that outrageously impressive stat from another perspective, shall we? 

-For ease of math. Let's say he's a career 300% hitter.

-This means on average. For every ten at bats. Derek, (or any other 300% hitter.)

-Will get at least 3 hits, correct? Or 300 hits out of every 1,000 plate appearances.

If on average he's successful 30% of the time.

-He's also wrong 70% of the time! (Meaning on average. Seven times out of ten. He's wrong or unsuccessful, correct? )

-Yet he still wound up in Major League Baseball's (MLB,s) prestigious "Hall Of Fame!" (Did he not?)

-Which he rightfully deserves to be!

-So what's a few key takeaways here? Just a couple.

-First, you and I definitely don't have to be perfect, in order to be extremely successful/great! Would you not agree?

-Second, Jeets had a career total of 3,465 total hits. ( And only 260 of them were homeruns!)

So you and I don't have to totally crush it. To be considered great!

-Meaning you don't have to constantly try and close the 7 & 8 figure transactions in a single or first try! 

So my 64,000 dollar question to you. My fellow profit seeking entrepreneurs.

Is simply this. Are you finally psychologically ready to add a little "Derek Jeter", incremental, bite sized like success.

To your overall long term to plan. For major success!

Please share your main key takeaways in the comments below!

postsData.content:
The corporate buzzwords don't make you sound smart.
They make you sound‚Ä¶ robotic. People roll their eyes and zone out.

If you want to be taken seriously, if you want to lead and inspire..

....talk like a real person. Lead like one.

Here is how:

1. ‚ÄúLeverage‚Äù
 Nobody wakes up thinking, ‚ÄúI need to leverage my morning coffee.‚ÄùJust say:
 ‚ÄúUse‚Äù or ‚ÄúTake advantage of.‚Äù

2. ‚ÄúBandwidth‚Äù
 You‚Äôre not a Wi-Fi signal.
 Just say ‚Äútime‚Äù or ‚Äúcapacity.‚Äù

3. ‚ÄúDrill down‚Äù
 You‚Äôre not drilling anything.
 Say ‚Äúlook into this more‚Äù or ‚Äúfocus on the details.‚Äù

4. ‚ÄúAlign‚Äù
 Corporate-speak for ‚Äúagree‚Äù or "let's coordinate"
 So just say that.

5. ‚ÄúGame changer‚Äù
 Unless you‚Äôre curing disease, it‚Äôs probably not.
 Try ‚Äúbig improvement‚Äù or ‚Äúreal impact.‚Äù

6. ‚ÄúSynergy‚Äù
 Nobody leaves a meeting saying, ‚ÄúWow, that synergy was incredible.‚Äù
 Just say ‚Äúworking well together‚Äù or ‚Äúteamwork.‚Äù

7. ‚ÄúOptics‚Äù
 Sounds like you care more about how something looks than what‚Äôs right.
 Say ‚Äúhow this looks‚Äù or ‚Äúthe impression it gives.‚Äù

8. ‚ÄúActionable insights‚Äù
 Insights don‚Äôt take action. People do.
 Use ‚Äúuseful advice‚Äù or ‚Äústeps we can take.‚Äù

9. ‚ÄúParadigm shift‚Äù
 People feel change. You don‚Äôt need a buzzword for it.
 Say ‚Äúa new way of thinking.‚Äù

Buzzwords make you blend in. Real words make you stand out.

Drop the jargon. Speak like a real person and watch how fast people start paying attention.

What‚Äôs the one buzzword you wish would disappear forever?

 Repost this if you‚Äôre done with corporate nonsense and followfor more posts like this.

postsData.content:
When I I became a Strategic Account Director for the first time, there was only one account I wanted to close: a $45B global airline. It took me 9 months, and we ended up winning a $5.9M deal.

Here‚Äôs how I did it, play-by-play ‚Üì


BACKSTORY:

I joined a Conversational AI company as a Strategic Account Director focused on CX transformation with Fortune 500 brands. On day 1, this was the account I was obsessed with winning above all others because I was a loyal flier and top customer with them.


THE BLUEPRINT:

1. Used the airline for the basis of my onboarding pitch.

During my first week of boot camp at my new company, we had to pick a brand to pitch, and I chose them. It went horribly wrong, but the good thing is that it was in front of internal stakeholders.

I learned so much about our product through my mistakes, but I learned even more about the airline through my extensive research.


2. Wrote an open letter for the airline executives based on my customer experience.

Here was the winning structure:

‚Ä¢ Kept it brief (2-3 min read)

‚Ä¢ Stated my case (importance of giving time back to customers, like me, using their visuals)

‚Ä¢ Defined a path forward (gave specific ideas they could use)

‚Ä¢ Delivered credibility (our brief history and a non-competitive customer example)

‚Ä¢ Provided a compelling call-to-action (invite to an exclusive peer event in London)


3. Sent an email to 5 execs with a private link to the open letter.

Here was the email:

Hello S**********,

As I write this from the <airline‚Äôs lounge>, I was reminded of just how many miles I fly when I received your letter with my annual <club membership> (attached).

I have been a <airline> loyalist for several years and this year is shaping up to be the year I finally hit <highest tier> status!

The experiences I receive from <airline>; from the friendly greetings at the gate, to the hospitality at the lounges, to the mobile app experience are all top notch!

But...

Link: Read The Open Letter to VPs

Look forward to connecting!

Brandon


4. I also sent physical packages to arrive on the same day as the email.

The packages included:

‚Ä¢ High-quality materials
‚Ä¢ Initial business case using public-facing info
‚Ä¢ Invitation to validate our numbers and connect

A few days after this was done, I received calls from 3 direct reports to the VPs I sent everything to.

That led to a successful 9-month engagement where we beat several competitors to win their business.


Bold, prepared, and creative wins.

Especially in this market!

Want to read the exact open letter I sent?

Unlock it here:

(Bonus inside)

Spiritual enlightenment and worldly enlightenment may seem similar, but they arise from distinct dimensions of experience and understanding. Worldly enlightenment often refers to intellectual knowledge, societal success, and the acquisition of external power or status. It is the awakening to the mechanics of the material world, where understanding leads to achievements, comforts, and control. This kind of enlightenment is bound by the transient nature of the physical realm, rooted in the ego‚Äôs pursuit of fulfillment through external means.

On the other hand, spiritual enlightenment transcends the confines of the material world. It is an awakening to the oneness of existence, where the illusion of separation dissolves and the soul recognizes its intrinsic unity with the divine. Spiritual enlightenment is not measured by what is acquired, but by what is surrendered‚Äîthe attachment to the ego, desires, and the illusion of control. It leads to inner peace, compassion, and an eternal connection to higher consciousness.

While worldly enlightenment may lead to temporary satisfaction, spiritual enlightenment leads to an unshakable peace that flows from within, beyond the realms of time and circumstance. It is a journey from the finite to the infinite.

Many entrepreneurs have an idea they believe could be the next big thing.

To test the waters, they create an MVP (Minimum Viable Product) to see if there‚Äôs a market for it.

Here are some tips for building a successful MVP:

1. ùêäùêûùêûùê© ùê¢ùê≠ ùê¨ùê¢ùê¶ùê©ùê•ùêû

Focus on the core functionality of your product or service. Don‚Äôt try to include too many features. You can always add more later based on feedback from users.

2. ùêÅùêÆùê¢ùê•ùêù ùê¢ùê≠ ùê™ùêÆùê¢ùêúùê§ùê•ùê≤

Time is of the essence when launching a new product or service. The sooner you can get your MVP out there, the sooner you can start gathering feedback and making improvements.

3. ùêÜùêûùê≠ ùêüùêûùêûùêùùêõùêöùêúùê§ ùêûùêöùê´ùê•ùê≤ ùêöùêßùêù ùê®ùêüùê≠ùêûùêß

User feedback is essential for refining your MVP and ensuring that it meets the needs of your target market.

Make sure to collect feedback at every stage of development, from early prototypes all the way to the final product.

4. ùêÅùêû ùê©ùê´ùêûùê©ùêöùê´ùêûùêù ùê≠ùê® ùê©ùê¢ùêØùê®ùê≠

As much as you may want your MVP to be perfect, chances are it won‚Äôt be.

Proper planning and foresight can make all the difference in bringing a great product to market.

Saying no isn‚Äôt rude‚Äîit‚Äôs necessary. 

You don‚Äôt have to please everyone or take on more than you can handle. 

Protect your time, set your limits, and focus on what truly matters.

The right people will respect your boundaries. The wrong ones will expose themselves.

Learn to say no without guilt.

comments.commentText: Agreed Ranveer Allahbadia . The ability to say no without guilt is a superpower. It‚Äôs easy to fall into the trap of pleasing everyone, but every unnecessary "yes" chips away at time, focus, and energy. The most successful people don‚Äôt just manage their time - they protect it fiercely. Because at the end of the day, you either run your schedule, or it runs you.

One more comment. Any of those nice ways to say no would have ended my relationship with the person or company that reached out to me. My agent told me to always say yes and he‚Äôd help me figure out how to get it done no matter what (ghost writers ) If I politely declined a project the company would hire someone else and never call me again. The new person they hired would then become their go to person (assuming they didn‚Äôt suck) and if that person was smart they would never say no or then they too would no longer be contacted. I have seen people say no within the corporate word though. You have more job security as an employee. Anyone providing creative services and providing content for game development needs to always say yes if they want and longevity with their career . My hats off to anyone who is able to level the playing field but generally the client is God as far as the vendor issaying this with all due respect. :)

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Setting boundaries is essential for both productivity and personal well-being. Saying no can be empowering!

Hindu texts describe the path to spiritual enlightenment as a multidimensional journey, uniquely tailored to the soul's innate tendencies and aspirations. It is not a linear path but rather a spiral, where the seeker moves through layers of self-realization, shedding illusion and attachment. The Bhagavad Gita, for example, speaks of three primary paths: Karma Yoga (the yoga of selfless action), Bhakti Yoga (the yoga of devotion), and Jnana Yoga (the yoga of knowledge), each guiding the seeker to the same ultimate truth‚Äîunion with the Divine.

However, the true essence of these paths lies not in their distinction, but in their convergence. Karma Yoga teaches that every action is an opportunity to transcend the ego and align with the higher self. Bhakti Yoga emphasizes a deep, intimate relationship with the Divine, where love becomes the vehicle for liberation. Jnana Yoga, on the other hand, calls for discernment, where one seeks to understand the nature of reality beyond appearances.

Ultimately, Hindu texts reveal that spiritual enlightenment is not an achievement to be attained but a realization to be uncovered‚Äîa return to one's eternal nature, beyond dualities, where the individual and the Divine are one.

Could soft robotic wearables transform assistive technologies?

Massachusetts Institute of Technology researchers have developed PneuAct, a tool that designs soft pneumatic actuators for assistive wearables and robotics.

#ùóòùó∫ùóØùóøùóÆùó∞ùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùóñùóÆùóπùóπ ùòÅùóº ùóüùó≤ùóÆùó±ùó≤ùóøùòÄùóµùó∂ùóΩ: ùó°ùóÆùòÉùó∂ùó¥ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóñùóµùóÆùóπùóπùó≤ùóªùó¥ùó≤ùòÄ
Leadership is a transformative journey that requires skill, vision, and resilience. Accepting this role means being prepared for misunderstanding, criticism, opposition, accusations, and rejection.

ùó°ùóÆùòÅùòÇùóøùó≤ ùóºùó≥ ùóüùó≤ùóÆùó±ùó≤ùóøùòÄùóµùó∂ùóΩ
Leadership involves making difficult decisions that may not please everyone. As a leader, you will be scrutinized, and your actions may be misinterpreted. Recognizing this reality helps you approach your role with a balanced perspective.

ùó†ùó∂ùòÄùòÇùóªùó±ùó≤ùóøùòÄùòÅùóÆùóªùó±ùó∂ùóªùó¥
Not everyone will agree with your vision. Misunderstandings often arise from differing perspectives. Instead of seeing this as a setback, view it as an opportunity to clarify your intentions and foster open communication.

ùó™ùó≤ùó∂ùó¥ùóµùòÅ ùóºùó≥ ùóñùóøùó∂ùòÅùó∂ùó∞ùó∂ùòÄùó∫
Criticism can be challenging, coming from various sources. However, not all criticism is detrimental; constructive feedback can promote growth. Learn to distinguish between helpful and harmful criticism to enhance your leadership.

ùó•ùó≤ùòÄùó∂ùóπùó∂ùó≤ùóªùó∞ùó≤
Resilience is crucial for leaders. Cultivate a thick skin while maintaining emotional intelligence. Respond thoughtfully to criticism, using it as a chance to adapt and promote a respectful team culture.

ùó¢ùóΩùóΩùóºùòÄùó∂ùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª
Leaders often encounter differing opinions. While opposition can feel isolating, it is part of the leadership experience. Embracing it can lead to deeper discussions and innovative solutions.

ùóüùó≤ùóÆùó±ùó≤ùóøùòÄùóµùó∂ùóΩ
Use opposition as an opportunity to engage your team in decision-making. Actively seek input from dissenters, which strengthens team dynamics and shows you value diverse perspectives.

ùóïùòÇùóøùó±ùó≤ùóª ùóºùó≥ ùóîùó∞ùó∞ùòÇùòÄùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùòÄ ùóÆùóªùó± ùó•ùó≤ùó∑ùó≤ùó∞ùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª
Accusations can feel personal, especially if based on misunderstandings. Stay composed and focus on your core values and motivations for leading.

ùó•ùó≤ùó∑ùó≤ùó∞ùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª ùó∂ùóªùòÅùóº ùó†ùóºùòÅùó∂ùòÉùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª
Rejection can be tough, but don‚Äôt let it discourage you. Reflect on the reasons behind it, learn from the experience, and let it fuel your commitment to your vision.

ùóùùóºùòÇùóøùóªùó≤ùòÜ ùóºùó≥ ùóÆ ùó•ùó≤ùòÄùó∂ùóπùó∂ùó≤ùóªùòÅ ùóüùó≤ùóÆùó±ùó≤ùóø
Accepting leadership is a brave choice filled with challenges. By facing misunderstandings and criticisms, you build resilience that inspires others. Great leaders embrace these challenges, leading to personal growth and the ability to navigate complexities with confidence and compassion.

postsData.content:
Stop Blocking Your Team‚Äôs Success 

Hotel owners, let‚Äôs be real for a second: hovering over your team like a helicopter manager is doing more harm than good.

Imagine this‚Äîyou've hired an incredible team, full of professionals who know their stuff. So why treat them like they need permission for every little thing?

Your front desk staff doesn‚Äôt need you watching over their shoulder. Your housekeeping team doesn‚Äôt need a micromanaging checklist for every single towel. Your managers don‚Äôt need constant approvals for decisions they were trained to make.

Trust your team. Empower them.

Because here‚Äôs the truth: micromanagement crushes creativity, kills motivation, and makes even the best employees want to run for the hills.

But when you give them ownership, something magical happens:
 They take initiative.
 They solve problems on their own.
 They create exceptional guest experiences without needing you to step in.

At the end of the day, you‚Äôre not paying for hours filled with check-ins and reports‚Äîyou‚Äôre paying for results.

So, how do you build a hotel team that thrives without you breathing down their necks?

 Hire the Right People ‚Äì Look for attitude and passion, not just skills. A positive mindset is everything in hospitality.

 Trust Their Expertise ‚Äì Give them clear goals, then let them run with it. You hired them for a reason!

 Flexibility is Your Friend ‚Äì Some thrive in the morning, others at night. Some need quick breaks to recharge. Let them find their flow.

 Encourage Independent Thinking ‚Äì Give your team the freedom to problem-solve instead of waiting for orders. That‚Äôs where real innovation happens.

 Lead Like a Mentor, Not a Boss ‚Äì Train your managers to guide and support, not micromanage.

The Bottom Line?

Your hotel doesn‚Äôt need another rule, another layer of approval, or another policy that slows your team down.

It needs trust.

It needs freedom.

It needs a leadership style that makes people WANT to give their best, not feel like they have to.

So, here‚Äôs the challenge: step back, let go, and watch your team rise.

postsData.content:
93% of employees say trust is key to performance. 

Only 21% trust their leaders. That‚Äôs a crisis.

I've spent 15 years studying workplace dynamics, and here's what most leaders get wrong about trust:

‚Ä¢ They think it's about grand gestures.
‚Ä¢ They focus on words over actions.
‚Ä¢ They rush to fix without understanding.

According to Harvard Business Review, the hidden cost of low trust is -
‚Ä¢ 2.5x higher employee turnover
‚Ä¢ 40% lower productivity
‚Ä¢ 74% more stress
‚Ä¢ Millions in lost revenue

Here's what actually builds unshakeable trust:

1. The Presence Principle
‚Üí Show up when things go wrong
‚Üí Listen without defending
‚Üí Make eye contact in difficult conversations

2. The Commitment Compound
‚Üí Make smaller promises
‚Üí Keep them religiously
‚Üí Stack wins over time

3. The Transparency Rule
‚Üí Share bad news early
‚Üí Admit what you don't know
‚Üí Explain the "why" behind decisions

4. The Recovery Protocol
‚Üí Own mistakes immediately
‚Üí Focus on solutions, not blame
‚Üí Follow up until resolved

5. The Consistency Code
‚Üí Same behavior in public and private
‚Üí Aligned words and actions
‚Üí Predictable responses to challenges

Warning Signs - Trust is Eroding:
‚Ä¢ Increased formal documentation
‚Ä¢ Whispered conversations
‚Ä¢ Defensive communication
‚Ä¢ Missing deadlines without explanation

‚Üí Remember, trust is build everyday and not only in boardroom discussions.
‚Üí Share your experience below and tag a leader who gets it right.

Repost this to help a manager become a better leader.
Followfor more leadership insights that actually work.

Tech Startup CEOs & Investors: Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, FinTech, SaaS, ChatGPT
Tech Startup CEOs & Investors: Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, FinTech, SaaS, ChatGPT
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM ‚Äì Part 4 ‚Äì Update Agent LEARNING
Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (all links in my comment below)

A report in Quanta magazine provides an example: The idea of a ‚Äúbank‚Äù has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more abstract, really different from what you‚Äôre seeing,‚Äù said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3 of this series.

In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not ‚Äúknow‚Äù anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights! Bridging neuroscience with AI offers incredible potential for true learning and expertise curation. Excited for Part 5!

But everything you want is on the other side of the wall.

I‚Äôm not special, well-educated, or have any extra advantages.

I just went to the other side of the wall.

Because it took 7 straight nos to get 5 straight yeses.

My offer has been alive for a little over one month.

It‚Äôs surprised the hell out of me the momentum it‚Äôs created.

And in the first 30 days, we‚Äôre over $11K cash collected.

I am so d*mn grateful for the opportunity to work with these amazing people.

Through the lens of thousands of personal failures.

postsData.content:
An objection can feel like a slap in the face (if you don't know how to handle it)

How I handle top 10 sales objections:

Every objection is an opportunity for discovery - peel the onion.

1 ‚ÄúEmail me in 3 months"
- What will happen in 3 months?

2 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not interested"
- Before I leave - Is <challenge> a priority right now? if not, what is?

3 ‚ÄúToo expensive‚Äù
- It sounds like you're comparing this to what you already have or just the value isn't there for you. Which one is it?

4 ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have the budget‚Äù
- Budget aside, is this even close to a priority for 2025?

5 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm locked into a contract with a competitor‚Äù
- Anything you‚Äôd want to improve with your current solution?

6 ‚Äútried it & it didn‚Äôt work for us‚Äù
- Could you tell me more about what didn‚Äôt work?

7 ‚ÄúWe just signed a contract with a provider‚Äù
- Would you want to explore other options before renewal, just to compare?

8 ‚ÄúWe already use a competitor‚Äù
- Would you be open to hearing 3 ways we differ?

9 ‚ÄúAll set for now‚Äù
- Just so I‚Äôm clear, what‚Äôs working well that you feel all set on?

10 I‚Äôm too busy right now
- Is there a better time, or should I send a quick summary by email?

Don't fight the objection, get to the real why.

That's the art of verbal judo.

How do you handle objections?

PS. I`m, follow me for tips on how to drive revenue from LinkedIn & Email

comments.commentText: Objections aren‚Äôt roadblocks‚Äîthey‚Äôre just detours to the real conversation. Ask the right question, and suddenly, "not interested" turns into "tell me more."

postsData.name:
ü¶æJepson Taylor
ü¶æJepson Taylor
postsData.content:
The future is all merit based, more than ever. I've noticed, in the past I would hire people who were REALLY smart (e.g. PhD in physics, top 60 global Kaggler, etc..). I noticed lately I don't care anymore. Last week at a hackathon I was talking to very neurodivergent developer, they sounded interesting, they said all the right technical things, the normal temptation to lean in was paused. I don't care what people say anymore, I don't care what they seem to know. I ONLY care how they perform on new benchmarks, if you can't land in the top 5% you're not interesting regardless of how you interview. Your merit is also no longer gauged by you alone, it is you + whatever AI agents you bring to the party. I love the idea of the idiot turned savant with AI, why not?

You could be the smartest person, historically, a mathematical genius, and now struggle to be employed in the new AI world. You could also be a nobody, a loser who hasn't been able to get a job for years, an expired , and now because of these new ML benchmarks companies are begging to hire you. They could care less about your employment history. I think the concept of Kaggle will die, it isn't robust enough to test the new talent the world needs. The exciting thing about this new future nobody knows where the talent will show up, Pakistan? Nigeria? Cuba? I don't care, if you're out there you'll be found. Your salary? Probably more than you've ever been paid before.

Edit: This post is geared towards AI researchers moving the needle, quant types. I've worked with great innovation teams in the past where... they don't have great soft skills, they can't interact with customers, but they can do miracles in 48hrs in code. For other roles, sure... you wouldn't depend on a system like this. For the super quants, I see no reason why you wouldn't. I would even consider the 'asshole' in this scenario, if they perform. Many people have an allergic reaction to that mindset.

More on this in the coming weeks.

Jon Davids

postsData.content:
This guy made $1.5B from the NFL. But he doesn't own a team. And he doesn't even play football.

I'm talking about Michael Rubin, CEO of Fanatics.

This is the company making branded merchandise for the NBA, WWE, NASCAR, and many more.

And how Michael got here was a wild ride.

Here's what happened.


1/ Early Years

Rewind to 1980. Michael is a young hustler learning the laws of commerce: supply and demand.

His first attempt is a ski shop that he opens at 14 years old. It's a disaster. But in the process he manages to get his hands on a bunch of merchandise for pennies on the dollar.

He flips the load for a quick $75K profit.

Now he‚Äôs in the game. And it‚Äôs about to get serious.


2/ One down

Michael keeps on buying and selling overstock product from big brands. He's getting pretty good at it.

Before long he's selling $50M a year.

Then he starts GSI Commerce He's building and buying more businesses. Bulking up to play with the giants.

And in 2011, one of those giants takes him out. Ebay buys GSI for $2.4B.

But we haven't even gotten to the good part.


3/ Sports magnate

Next Michael pulls another baller move. He buys back a little chunk of GSI from eBay.

This chunk includes Fanatics, which makes branded clothing for sports leagues.

He modernizes the company with things like real-time manufacturing, eCommerce, and a bunch of new licensing deals.

Growth explodes.

Today, Fanatics is a juggernaut. Valued at $30B.

And the biggest investor in its latest funding round?

The NFL.


4/ My Take

Michael's approach is so simple, with relentless execution.

The concept of a "mastermind" can be a strange one to grasp, but Jay Fairbrother explains what it is. He writes: 

=====

"Napoleon Hill coined the term 'mastermind' in his book The Law of Success, which was first published in 1928. He wrote that when you put one person with a brain in a room along with another person and their brain, you create a third invisible, intangible force‚Äîthe mastermind.

A true mastermind is typically an intimate, smaller group of people who start together, stay together, and grow together in a mastermind for a year or more. Masterminds usually consist of groups of 8‚Äì14 people. The collective knowledge, experience, and wisdom of these 8‚Äì14 brains create a significant, powerful force. I actually stayed in one mastermind for 17 years. 17 years! Now that‚Äôs stickiness.

The idea behind a mastermind is to build in accountability and implementation. It‚Äôs to activate the power of the group to act as cheerleaders, supporters, and accountability peers. You‚Äôre creating a group dynamic where everyone supports each other and works together to help everyone succeed, rather than leaving each person to fend for themselves."

=====

Jay will be sharing his process for creating, and selling, a successful mastermind in the live masterclass that he's doing in a few days.

It's happening on Tuesday, February 11th at 12 pm Eastern, and the registration link is the comments!

postsData.content:
Your energy is everything.
But most people waste it without even noticing.
Not because they do too much. But because they spend it on the wrong things.


 Saying yes when you want to say no.
 Over-explaining when silence would do.
 Forcing small talk when you‚Äôd rather listen.
 Keeping up with conversations that drain you.


You feel it.


That heaviness after too much people time.
The exhaustion of trying to keep up.


It is not just in your head.

Your energy is not infinite.


Ever had a conversation that left you completely drained?
Sat through a meeting where you barely spoke, yet felt exhausted after?
Agreed to plans, then spent the whole time wishing you were home?

That is not just social fatigue.
That is energy leakage.


And here is the thing.

It adds up. 


Every time you give your energy away without intention,
you have less for what actually matters.

 Less for deep work.
 Less for real connection.
 Less for the things that make you feel alive.


Every choice either fuels you or drains you. Ô∏è


And when you protect it,
everything changes.


 More focus.
 More presence.
 More ease in how you move through the world.


Protecting your energy is not selfish.
It is survival.


Now.
Imagine what you could build with that energy.

 The ideas you could bring to life.
 The life you could create on your terms.


Your energy is yours.
Spend it where it truly matters.



I am, and my mission is to help introverted entrepreneurs and professionals thrive as they are while protecting their energy to focus on their dreams.
